article.title:
Teen friendships: navigating conflict and building resilience

paragraphs.english: Leo and his best friend attended the same primary and secondary schools. However, after Leo joined the school's football team, they began to spend less time together. During a heated confrontation, his friend lashed out, accusing Leo of ignoring him for his new teammates. It seemed like this could be the end of their friendship.

implication.english: ğŸ’¡ Friendship conflicts often arise from changing life circumstances and priorities. Leo's situation shows how extracurricular activities can unintentionally create distance in long-term friendships.

paragraphs.english: This situation is common among teens, according to Katie Leung Pui-yan, a child and family therapist at Therapy Partners in Hong Kong. She emphasised the significance of developing resilience in friendships. 'It helps them navigate major life transitions. When someone whom we are used to in our life is suddenly gone, resilience helps us to stand on our own two feet and make new friendships,' she said.

implication.english: ğŸ’¡ Resilience in friendships is a crucial life skill that helps teens cope with loss and change. Therapists emphasize it as a foundation for healthy social development.

paragraphs.english: Making new friends can be tough for teens who already have to juggle schoolwork, extracurriculars and family responsibilities. It can also be difficult for teenagers to express themselves if they have been judged for sharing their feelings.

implication.english: ğŸ’¡ Teens face multiple pressures that can hinder social connection. Past negative experiences with vulnerability make it harder to open up to new people.

paragraphs.english: Leo wanted to explain to his best friend that he had to balance football practice with schoolwork. However, he was also concerned about being perceived as weak. 'I just wished he saw how hard I struggled instead of always blaming me for being busy after school,' the 17-year-old said.

implication.english: ğŸ’¡ Fear of appearing weak often prevents teens from expressing their true feelings. Mutual understanding requires both parties to acknowledge each other's struggles.

paragraphs.english: Leung explained that conflicts among friends arise due to differing values held by each individual. 'Conflict happens naturally [as a] result of different perspectives,' she said. 'Once you accept that disagreement is normal, you can focus on a healthy recovery.'

implication.english: ğŸ’¡ Reframing conflict as natural rather than negative helps teens approach disagreements constructively. Acceptance is the first step toward resolution.

paragraphs.english: Leung offered advice on resolving conflicts with friends. First, take time to calm down and recognise your emotions, which may change from anger to sadness or a need for justice. Then, talk to your friend again and use 'I statements' to express your point of view without accusing them of wrongdoing. 'Their reaction will tell you everything; if they still cannot respond with empathy after you've been honest, it's time to consider if you should move on,' Leung said.

implication.english: ğŸ’¡ Effective conflict resolution involves emotional regulation and non-accusatory communication. A friend's response to vulnerability is a reliable indicator of relationship health.

paragraphs.english: The therapist emphasised the importance of keeping an open mind when listening to others. Immediately disagreeing can make the other person feel defensive and unheard. Instead, try to restate what you've heard and acknowledge the other person's feelings.

implication.english: ğŸ’¡ Active listeningâ€”restating and acknowledgingâ€”builds trust and defuses conflict. Defensive reactions escalate tension.

paragraphs.english: Leo realised that he and his best friend both wanted to spend more time together before graduating, and they are both making an effort to repair their friendship.

implication.english: ğŸ’¡ Shared goals and mutual effort are essential for friendship repair. Recognizing common ground paves the way for reconciliation.

paragraphs.english: But not all conflicts will have a positive outcome. Leung drew attention to three friendship killers: judgment, minimisation and dismissal. Judgment occurs when someone considers a friend's actions or feelings to be wrong or trivial. Minimisation involves downplaying their experience, believing they have overreacted. Dismissal could mean ignoring the issue by changing the subject or avoiding a response.

implication.english: ğŸ’¡ Recognizing toxic patterns (judgment, minimisation, dismissal) helps teens identify when friendships are beyond repair. These behaviors erode trust and respect.

paragraphs.english: Leung also emphasised the risk of relying on a single social circle, as group dynamics are constantly changing. Friendships often dissolve due to shifting interests. Building resilience in friendships also involves having a range of social outlets. 'Whether it's through volunteering and community work [or] dance lessons, having backup communities outside of school ensures you always have a supportive group to turn to,' Leung said.

implication.english: ğŸ’¡ Diversifying social circles is a proactive resilience strategy. Hobbies and community activities provide emotional backup when primary friendships fail.
